text:
Fulton Fish Market: Manhattan's supply of fresh fish being unloaded and transferred to horse-drawn wagons. Note the Woolworth Tower in the background.

About, 1920

Ewing Galloway
title: Fulton Fish Market.

text:
Fulton Street, north side, west from but not including South, to and including Front Streets. The view shows the south side of the Fulton Street Fish Market.

1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) 103-94 South Street, west side, south from, but not including Beek- man, to, but not including Fulton Streets, showing the Fulton Fish Market (formerly a car barn), occupying the entire block. It is reputed to be the world's largest of its kind. In the background are shown (left to right), The Farmer's Loan and Trust Co., No. 60 Wall Street Tower and the Bank of Manhattan Co. buildings.

January 31, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A detail of the same, showing Nos. 96 and 97 only. Note the rest- aurant and a display of hardware keeping close company.

1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) 103-94 South Street, west side, south from, but not including Beek- man, to, but not including Fulton Streets, showing the Fulton Fish Market (formerly a car barn), occupying the entire block. It is reputed to be the world's largest of its kind. In the background are shown (left to right), The Farmer's Loan and Trust Co., No. 60 Wall Street Tower and the Bank of Manhattan Co. buildings.

January 31, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A detail of the same, showing Nos. 96 and 97 only. Note the rest- aurant and a display of hardware keeping close company.

1923.

P. L. Sperr.

Fulton Fish Market: Fish buyers examining packaged goods in the middle of Peck Slip. These boxes, after being auctioned are then delivered to the purchaser's place of business by the independent truckman.

P. L. Sperr

1923
Views 1, 2, 3

text:
Fulton Fish Market: A series of three views showing activity at the market building on South Street. View 1 shows peddlers' wagons and delivery trucks drawn up to the curb; No's. 2&3, the commodity handled here.

title: Fulton fish market - [Market building on South Street.]

text:
(1) Piers 17 and 16, East River, east side of South Street. This view is from end of Pier 18 (North Dock), utilized by the Fulton Fish Market. The Fulton Street Ferry House is shown between Piers Nos. 17 and 16. About 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view from the rivers edge, and viewing southward. August 20, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another close-up; but from a slightly different angle. About 1923.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Piers 16-17 - Manhattan - South Street - [Fulton Street ferry house.]

text:
(1) Piers 17 and 16, East River, east side of South Street. This view is from end of Pier 18 (North Dock), utilized by the Fulton Fish Market. The Fulton Street Ferry House is shown between Piers Nos. 17 and 16. About 1923.

title: East River - Piers 16-17 - Manhattan - South Street - [Fulton Street ferry house.]

text:
South Street, east side, at the foot of Fulton Street, showing the ferry house of the former Fulton Street Ferry, which was operated to Fulton Street in Brooklyn, by the Union Ferry Co. Adjacent to same, on the south, is Pier No. 16, East River, occupied by the United Fruit Co. Across the background, appears the Brooklyn Bridge. This set consists of three views, more or less similar; taken at the same time.

July 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

South Street, east side, at the foot of Fulton Street, showing the ferry house of the former Fulton Street Ferry, which was operated to Fulton Street in Brooklyn, by the Union Ferry Co. Adjacent to same, on the south, is Pier No. 16, East River, occupied by the United Fruit Co. Across the background, appears the Brooklyn Bridge. This set consists of three views, more or less similar; taken at the same time.

July 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

South Street, east side, at the foot of Fulton Street, showing the ferry house of the former Fulton Street Ferry, which was operated to Fulton Street in Brooklyn, by the Union Ferry Co. Adjacent to same, on the south, is Pier No. 16, East River, occupied by the United Fruit Co. Across the background, appears the Brooklyn Bridge. This set consists of three views, more or less similar; taken at the same time.

July 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

East River, showing the Fulton Ferry Slip, off South Street, at the foot of Fulton Street. The slip was demolished between 1925 and 1930. (See G.W. Bromley maps). In the right background is seen the Woolworth Building.

June 12, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Fulton Ferry Slip.

text:
(1) Fulton Street, south side, west from south Street, to and including Front Street.  Also shown is South Street, west side, south from and including Fulton Street, to Burling Slip.  A portion of Fulton Market is seen on the right.

May 29, 1932

P. L. Sperr

(2) The same, a different angle and showing a further view westward on Fulton Street.

February 2, 1928

P. L. Sperr

(1) Fulton Street, south side, west from south Street, to and including Front Street.  Also shown is South Street, west side, south from and including Fulton Street, to Burling Slip.  A portion of Fulton Market is seen on the right.

May 29, 1932

P. L. Sperr

(2) The same, a different angle and showing a further view westward on Fulton Street.

February 2, 1928

P. L. Sperr

(1) 93 to 88 South Street, west side, south from and including Fulton Street (right), to and including Burling Slip, as seen from Pier 17, East River. Also shown, is Fulton Street, south side, west from South Street. In the background is visible a general view of the tall buildings dominating the immediate area, with the tower of the Woolworth Building on the extreme right. September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view. September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.  Neg. # 1586

(3) The same, as seen from the east side of the street. Also shown, is a close view of Nos. 4 to 14 Fulton Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of South Street. NEG # 3148 September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(1) 93 to 88 South Street, west side, south from and including Fulton Street (right), to and including Burling Slip, as seen from Pier 17, East River. Also shown, is Fulton Street, south side, west from South Street. In the background is visible a general view of the tall buildings dominating the immediate area, with the tower of the Woolworth Building on the extreme right. September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view. September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.  Neg. # 1586

(3) The same, as seen from the east side of the street. Also shown, is a close view of Nos. 4 to 14 Fulton Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of South Street. NEG # 3148 September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(1) 93 to 88 South Street, west side, south from and including Fulton Street (right), to and including Burling Slip, as seen from Pier 17, East River. Also shown, is Fulton Street, south side, west from South Street. In the background is visible a general view of the tall buildings dominating the immediate area, with the tower of the Woolworth Building on the extreme right. September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view. September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.  Neg. # 1586

(3) The same, as seen from the east side of the street. Also shown, is a close view of Nos. 4 to 14 Fulton Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of South Street. NEG # 3148 September 23, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

93-89 South Street (left), at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of Fulton Street. Also shown are Nos. 4 and 6 Fulton Street (right), adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of South Street. No. 93 (the corner house), does not bear any numbers on the latter street. Prominently silhouetted against the sky, are (left to right), the Farmer's Loan and Trust Co.; 60 Wall Street Tower and the Bank of Manhattan Buildings.

May 29, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
East River, shoreline, east from James Slip (left) to Pike Slip, showing (left to right) piers 26 (Lackawanna Railroad), 27, 28 and 29. Also shown center is the Hearst Publications Building on South Street, from Catherine to Market Slips, and across it, the Knickerbocker Village real estate development. Overhead appears the Brooklyn Bridge and to its right the Manhattan Bridge. The point of vantage is the dock at the foot of Fulton Street, Brooklyn.
July 31, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a different angle and including piers 30 and 31 (right). Also shown (left) are, the Municipal and Woolworth Buildings.
June 8, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, another view, and showing a portion of the Brooklyn Bridge (left).

P. L. Sperr.

text:
100 South Street, west side, between Fulton and Beekman Streets. Shown is a portion of Fulton Market.

1936.

W.P.A. photo.
Federal Writers Project.

South Street, east side, north from the foot of Fulton Street, showing the southerly unit of the Fulton Fish Market pier buildings. The northerly unit is just beyond and is totally obscured from view. Note the Brooklyn Bridge in the background.

1: August 2, 1937
2: Sept. 3, 1940

P. L. Sperr
